replies.bodyText: @benradey Can you paste the code verbatim into a comment? Or an example?
replies.author: stoobie

replies.bodyText:
server: http://localhost:8080
repositories:
  - name: pantheonSampleRepo
    attributes: path/to/attribute.adoc

    modules:
      - master.adoc
      - modules/*.adoc

    resources:
      - shared/legal.adoc
      - shared/foreword.adoc
      - resources/*
replies.author: benradey

replies.bodyText:
@benradey I have some questions:

Why is the name of the structure in the plural (repositories)? Can you have more than one repository?
There is a note in lines 29-30 that says:
## Note: Due to yaml syntax, any filepaths that start with a wildcard must be surrounded in quotes like so:
# modules:
#  - '*.adoc'
However in your example, you don't include the quotes around the wildcards. Should I remove that note?
The first part of the config file includes guidance. Can I see the entire file now? I'll probably remove that part so the documentation will have less to keep synched.
replies.author: stoobie

replies.bodyText:
Sort of, yes. Because the attributes file is a repository-wide setting, if you have multiple attributes files that you build documents with, then you will be setting up multiple pantheon repositories. This isn't officially supported yet, but it's on the radar, so we are setting the stage for that now.
The quotes are only necessary if the line starts with the wildcard. If there's a wildcard in the middle of the entry, then the quotes aren't necessary.
What I pasted is the entirety of what the uploader actually reads. I stripped out the surrounding comments. So assuming your question was a question and not a request that I misunderstood, the answer is "yes, that is the entire file."
replies.author: benradey

timeline.bodyText:
This sounds confusing to me, since 'name' is a unique name that would show up in the user facing URL and cannot be confused with the git url.
Here is my recommendation:
name : A unique name that {ProductShortName} uses to reference the URL of the repository.
Let's say for rhel-8 docs, it can be name: rhel-8-docs or any other unique string that the authors like.
